forecast.review: Forecaster 2’s case rests heavily on the research assistant’s snapshot showing a Liberal seat projection of 188–196 and a national vote lead with 8 days to go. That snapshot conflicts with the fixed Oct 2025 election date and with the long-running 2024 polling picture; without independent corroboration, I view it as unreliable. Their acknowledgement of correlated polling/model error and late-campaign volatility is sound, but the high 78% hinges on a premise I discount. Forecaster 3 aligns with my prior view: they emphasize durable fundamentals (leadership approval, affordability/housing salience, fundraising, ON 905 dynamics, Bloc competition) and the scale of the lift required to reach 172, akin to 2015. Those structural points strengthen the No case. The added emphasis on fundraising and leadership favourables is a useful complement I hadn’t explicitly weighed, and it pushes me modestly lower. I find F3’s reasoning more convincing than F2’s because it is better anchored to consistent, longer-run evidence and doesn’t rely on the questionable snapshot.
forecast.rationale: I continue to discount the assistant’s report given timing inconsistencies and lack of corroboration. The baseline through late 2024 had the Conservatives well ahead; for the Liberals to reach 172+ would require a broad and efficient surge in Ontario and Quebec, plus containment of NDP/Bloc leakage—conditions not indicated by the longer-run data and fundamentals (leadership headwinds, affordability salience, fundraising gaps). Campaigns can swing, leadership changes or major CPC missteps could re-open the map, and FPTP can amplify regional shifts, so I don’t go as low as 5%. But given the majority threshold and current fundamentals, my prior 17% looks a bit high. I’m adjusting down modestly to reflect the structural barriers highlighted by Forecaster 3 while still reserving some probability for large-swing scenarios or strategic consolidation late in the campaign.
